question: If the Rayleigh parameter ρ in the Lorenz-63 system is decreased below the classical chaos threshold, would the chaotic attractor collapse to simpler periodic or fixed-point behavior?
If σ is increased while ρ and β are held fixed at their standard chaotic values, must Lorenz-63 become more chaotic?
If β is made very large in the Lorenz-63 system, is it reasonable to expect trajectories to be strongly damped toward a non-chaotic regime?
If active control is used to constantly reset initial-condition errors in Lorenz-63, does the underlying system stop being chaotic?
If parameters F and G in Lorenz-84 are reduced to small values, would chaotic oscillations likely disappear in favor of simple behavior?
If Lorenz-84 is linearized around an equilibrium with weak forcing, would chaos persist in the linearized model?
If the nonlinear interaction coefficients in Lorenz-84 are weakened, is it reasonable to expect chaos to weaken or vanish?
If the forcing F in Lorenz-96 is gradually reduced to zero, does the system approach a non-chaotic fixed-point regime?
If the dimension N of Lorenz-96 increases while F is fixed, must the level of chaos always increase?
If additional dissipative terms are added to Lorenz-96, can chaotic energy transfer be expected to weaken?
If parameter c in the Rössler system is lowered sufficiently, can the chaotic attractor collapse to a periodic orbit?
If the key nonlinear term responsible for folding trajectories in the Rössler system is removed, will chaos persist?
If a weak periodic forcing term is added to the Rössler system, must the chaotic behavior necessarily increase?
If parameter c in the Chen system is moved out of its chaotic regime, will chaotic oscillations vanish?
If (a, b, c) in the Chen system are tuned to numerically match Lorenz parameters, does that guarantee topological equivalence to the Lorenz system?
If the nonlinear coupling terms in the Chen system are greatly weakened, is it reasonable to expect chaos to diminish?
If the external current parameter I in the Hindmarsh–Rose model is reduced into a regular spiking regime, would chaotic bursting be expected to disappear?
If noise is added to the Hindmarsh–Rose model, does the underlying determinism of the chaotic dynamics vanish?
If a slow variable governing recovery dynamics is removed from Hindmarsh–Rose, must chaos disappear?
If the recovery parameter b in the FitzHugh–Nagumo model is adjusted so that the limit cycle is lost, can the system become purely excitable without periodic firing?
If the stimulus current I is made extremely large in FitzHugh–Nagumo, must the system become chaotic?
If ε tends to zero in FitzHugh–Nagumo, does the system necessarily develop chaotic bursting?
If parameter B in the Brusselator is taken below the Hopf bifurcation threshold, do oscillations disappear in favor of a fixed point?
If parameter A is made extremely large in the Brusselator, must chaos appear in this two-dimensional system?
If small external noise is added to the periodic Brusselator, does it become a chaotic system?
If parameter q in the Oregonator is varied so that the system re-enters a simple periodic regime, is it expected that chaos disappears?
If ε is made extremely small in the Oregonator, does that automatically guarantee chaotic behavior?
If the Oregonator is weakly coupled to another periodic oscillator, must chaotic behavior intensify?
If the forcing amplitude γ in the Duffing oscillator is reduced to zero, does the system lose its chaotic behavior?
If damping δ in the Duffing oscillator is changed slightly, must the level of chaos change monotonically?
If the nonlinear stiffness term x^3 in the Duffing oscillator is replaced by a purely linear term, would chaos persist?
If the noise scale σ in the Ornstein–Uhlenbeck process is reduced to zero, does the process become deterministic?
If the mean-reversion rate θ is increased while σ is fixed, does the randomness of the OU process disappear?
If the long-term mean μ is shifted but σ and θ are unchanged, does the qualitative randomness of the OU process change?
If the domain length of the Kuramoto–Sivashinsky equation is reduced below a critical scale, can spatiotemporal chaos disappear?
If the stabilizing fourth-order dissipation term in the KS equation is made much stronger, is it reasonable to expect chaos to weaken or vanish?
If the nonlinear term u·u_x is removed from the KS equation, can spatiotemporal chaos persist?
If a small periodic forcing term is added to the sine–Gordon equation, does that automatically produce chaos?
If integrability-breaking perturbations of sufficient strength are added to sine–Gordon, can chaotic behavior appear?
If solitons in sine–Gordon collide elastically in the integrable regime, does this lead to chaotic dynamics?
If parameter u in the Ikeda map is reduced significantly below 0.9, is it expected that chaotic dynamics will weaken or disappear?
If the phase term t_n in the Ikeda map becomes nearly constant, can the map remain chaotic?
If external noise is added to the Ikeda map, does deterministic chaos simply turn into pure randomness in its governing laws?
If parameter a in the Hénon map is reduced into a periodic window, will the chaotic attractor collapse into a periodic orbit?
If parameter b in the Hénon map tends to zero, is chaos expected to disappear?
If a and b in the Hénon map are changed slightly from their classical values, must the system remain chaotic?
If K in the Standard Map is taken very close to zero, does the system approach an integrable, quasi-periodic regime?
If K is increased far above the critical value for widespread chaos, do most invariant tori break down?
If initial conditions are chosen strictly inside a surviving invariant torus, do those trajectories exhibit chaos?
If K approaches zero in the Circle Map, does it reduce to a rigid irrational rotation when Ω is irrational?
If Ω in the Circle Map is changed from irrational to rational, does the motion become periodic?
If the nonlinearity parameter K is made large while Ω remains irrational, must the Circle Map become chaotic?
If r in the logistic map is slowly decreased from 4.0, do periodic windows appear along the route away from fully developed chaos?
If independent noise is added to logistic_r4, does the logistic map cease to be deterministic in its evolution rule?
If the update rule of the logistic map is replaced by a purely linear function, can chaotic dynamics persist?
If r in the logistic map is increased slightly above 2.8, does the system remain in a non-chaotic regime for a range of r values?
If r is increased through the period-doubling cascade, is it expected that chaos will eventually emerge?
If r is decreased below 2.8, does the logistic map stay in a stable fixed-point regime?
If damping is added to a simple harmonic oscillator with no external forcing, does chaos appear?
If the amplitude of a simple harmonic oscillator is made very large while keeping it linear, does chaos arise?
If the frequency of SHM is slowly varied but the system remains linear, is chaos expected to appear?
If μ in the Van der Pol oscillator is made very small, does the system approach simple harmonic motion?
If μ in the Van der Pol oscillator is increased to a large value but the system remains two-dimensional and autonomous, must chaos arise?
If the Van der Pol oscillator is periodically forced, can chaotic motion occur for some parameter choices?
If predator mortality is increased moderately in the Lotka–Volterra model, can closed orbits persist without chaos?
If self-limiting terms are added to both species in the Lotka–Volterra system, does this guarantee the onset of chaos?
If both growth parameters are reduced while keeping the model form the same, is it reasonable that the system remains non-chaotic?
If the forcing amplitude in the damped-driven pendulum is increased enough, can the system enter a chaotic regime?
If the damping coefficient in the damped-driven pendulum is increased while forcing is small, is chaos likely to appear?
If the forcing frequency is tuned to match the natural frequency but the forcing amplitude remains small, must chaos occur?
